content:
<span class="word-wrap-span">Accusationspan>s of “reverse <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>” haunt an American professor

START with this truth of American society: disparaging <span class="word-wrap-span">remarkspan>s about white people as a whole that would be simply <span class="word-wrap-span">im<span class="word-wrap-span">permissiblespan>span> for other sets of people are largely <span class="word-wrap-span">permissiblespan> and carry few <span class="word-wrap-span">repercussionspan>s. This fact seems to <span class="word-wrap-span">enthrallspan> the left and enrage the right. Sarah Jeong, a newly hired editorial writer for the New York Times , found herself <span class="word-wrap-span">embroilspan>ed in a <span class="word-wrap-span">controversyspan> of this sort after critics <span class="word-wrap-span">dredgespan>d up her old tweets on white people. 

Ms Jeong wondered: “Are white people <span class="word-wrap-span">geneticallyspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">predisposespan>d to burn faster in the sun, thus <span class="word-wrap-span">logicallyspan> being only fit to live underground like grovelling <span class="word-wrap-span">goblinspan>s.” In another, she noted: “It’s kind of sick how much joy I get out of being cruel to old white men”. And she commented: “White people have stopped breeding. You’ll all go <span class="word-wrap-span">extinctspan> soon. This was my plan all along.”

Right-wing <span class="word-wrap-span">punditspan>s were <span class="word-wrap-span">outragespan>d. The favourite thought experiment for this crowd is the substitution test—imagining the <span class="word-wrap-span">consequencespan>s of similar statements, with the word “black” replaced for “white”. Yet Ms Jeong kept her job (and the Times says it reviewed her previous social-media posts before she was hired). She would surely have never been offered the job if the target had been a minority. 

Those on the left came up with different philosophies to explain her behaviour. One was that, as an Asian-American woman, she was <span class="word-wrap-span">incapablespan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">altspan>ogether. Another was that it was really the critics who had <span class="word-wrap-span">excavatespan>d Ms Jeong’s public statements who were <span class="word-wrap-span">racistspan>s. For her part, Ms Jeong labelled her extreme statements as “counter-trolling” the <span class="word-wrap-span">delugespan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">sexistspan>, <span class="word-wrap-span">racistspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">homophobicspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">slurspan>s directed at her. She expressed her regret and said she understood “how <span class="word-wrap-span">hurtfulspan> these posts are out of context”. This strains <span class="word-wrap-span">credulityspan>, given that her posts span August 2013 to November 2015, but that is no matter.

The <span class="word-wrap-span">fundamentalspan> point that people on the left make is that stereotyping white people is not as bad as stereotyping blacks, Asians, Muslims, immigrants and so on because whites have <span class="word-wrap-span">dominatespan>d America since its founding. The question they prefer to debate is whether so-called “reverse <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>” is as harmful as the more conventional sort of <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>—which, of course, it is not. But the defeat of one false <span class="word-wrap-span">equivalencespan> does not <span class="word-wrap-span">sanctifyspan> the practice. Belittling, totalising comments about a people based on their skin colour is still a <span class="word-wrap-span">facilespan>, unhelpfully tribal and <span class="word-wrap-span">meaninglesslyspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">antagonisticspan> practice, even if a <span class="word-wrap-span">shamefulspan> history of systemic <span class="word-wrap-span">oppressionspan> does not <span class="word-wrap-span">lurkspan> behind it.

This is <span class="word-wrap-span">illustratespan>d by another recent <span class="word-wrap-span">controversyspan>, which has received less attention than Ms Jeong’s hiring by the Times . James <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan>, a professor of history at Rutgers University in New Jersey and living in <span class="word-wrap-span">Harlemspan>, took to Facebook to register his <span class="word-wrap-span">disapprovalspan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">gentrificationspan> in colourful terms: “OK, officially, I now hate white people…I just went to <span class="word-wrap-span">Harlemspan> Shake on 124 and Lenox for a <span class="word-wrap-span">Classicspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">burgerspan> to go…and the place is <span class="word-wrap-span">overrunspan> with little Caucasian <span class="word-wrap-span">assholesspan> who know their parents will <span class="word-wrap-span">approvespan> of anything they do,” he wrote in May. Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan>, himself white, then added, “I <span class="word-wrap-span">herebyspan> resign from my race. <span class="word-wrap-span">Fuckspan> these people.” 

When Facebook removed his post for violating “community standards on hate speech”, he protested further. “I just don’t want little Caucasians <span class="word-wrap-span">overrunspan>ning my life, as they did last night. Please God <span class="word-wrap-span">remandspan> them to the suburbs where they and their parents can colonise every restaurant, all the while <span class="word-wrap-span">pretendspan>ing that the <span class="word-wrap-span">idioticspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">indulgencespan> of their <span class="word-wrap-span">privilegespan> signifies <span class="word-wrap-span">cosmopolitanspan>—you know, as in <span class="word-wrap-span">sophisticatespan>d ‘European’—<span class="word-wrap-span">commitmentspan>s.”

Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan> faced a <span class="word-wrap-span">barragespan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">criticismspan>. His ravings <span class="word-wrap-span">overshadowspan>ed whatever point he was attempting to make about <span class="word-wrap-span">gentrificationspan>: he <span class="word-wrap-span">articulatespan>d no thought more <span class="word-wrap-span">sophisticatespan>d than white people should remain outside of <span class="word-wrap-span">Harlemspan>. But did his <span class="word-wrap-span">remarkspan>s rise to the level of <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>? 

Rutgers, his employer, thinks so. It found that Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan> violated university policy on <span class="word-wrap-span">harassmentspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">discriminationspan> because of <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">racialspan>span>ly-charged comments. The <span class="word-wrap-span">investigativespan> report <span class="word-wrap-span">explicitlyspan> employs the substitution test—replacing the word “black” for “Caucasian” and “white”—and noting that it would be <span class="word-wrap-span">im<span class="word-wrap-span">permissiblespan>span>. “From a legal and policy <span class="word-wrap-span">perspectivespan>,” the <span class="word-wrap-span">memospan> says, “‘reverse <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>’, to the extent it is defined as treating someone unfairly because they are white, is indeed possible and <span class="word-wrap-span">prohibitspan>ed”.

Because Rutgers is a public institution, Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan> has significant <span class="word-wrap-span">latitudespan> under the First <span class="word-wrap-span">Amendmentspan> to make anti-<span class="word-wrap-span">gentrificationspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">broadsidespan>s in <span class="word-wrap-span">inflammatoryspan> terms. On these grounds, the university is probably unable to <span class="word-wrap-span">censurespan> him. The <span class="word-wrap-span">Foundationspan> for Individual Rights in Education, a free-speech <span class="word-wrap-span">advocacyspan> group, has sent a strongly worded letter to the university president threatening legal action if the finding is not reversed. 

But the broader question—whether Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan>’s comments are <span class="word-wrap-span">racistspan> or not—is trickier. In a post defending his comments, titled “<span class="word-wrap-span">Confessionspan>s of a Race <span class="word-wrap-span">Traitorspan>”, Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan> writes that he cannot be guilty of reverse <span class="word-wrap-span">Racismspan> because it does not exist. “<span class="word-wrap-span">Racismspan> is the <span class="word-wrap-span">exclusivespan> property of white, mostly European people in this part of the world (the Western <span class="word-wrap-span">hemispherespan>),” he writes. This seems an odd position—a kind of <span class="word-wrap-span">mandatespan>d <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">racialspan>span> blindspot that both the university left and left-leaning journalists have adopted. In America Latinos are quite capable of being <span class="word-wrap-span">racistspan> towards blacks, and vice versa. In the rest of the world, <span class="word-wrap-span">discriminationspan> based on skin colour can be found from sub-Saharan Africa to East Asia.

One journalist has suggested that all comments disparaging whites should be taken as <span class="word-wrap-span">satiricalspan> and non-<span class="word-wrap-span">literalspan>, while those directed against minority groups should not. <span class="word-wrap-span">Straightforwardspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">advocacyspan> for the <span class="word-wrap-span">genocidespan> of white people—such as a tweet urging followers to “Kill all white people”—surely qualifies as <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>, if the word is to <span class="word-wrap-span">retainspan> its common meaning. Yet your <span class="word-wrap-span">correspondentspan>’s <span class="word-wrap-span">informalspan> poll of several left-leaning friends from university suggests that they are squeamish about labelling even such an extreme statement as anti-white <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>. To admit that would trivialise traditional <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>, they feared.

A much more <span class="word-wrap-span">sensiblespan> position would be to say that reverse <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan> can exist, but that it is rare in comparison to examples of <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan> against historically marginalised groups and almost always less harmful. That would allow for those on the left to continue in their project of calling out <span class="word-wrap-span">oppressionspan> without having to <span class="word-wrap-span">constructspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">convolutedspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">justificationspan>s for thoughtless statements like Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Livingstonspan>’s.

This is more than an <span class="word-wrap-span">esotericspan> academic debate. The <span class="word-wrap-span">altspan>-right and white supremacists thrive on stories of anti-white <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>—nothing makes for better <span class="word-wrap-span">propagandaspan> than the sense of a <span class="word-wrap-span">conspiracyspan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">oppressorspan>s. Already, 55% of white Americans believe that they suffer from <span class="word-wrap-span">discriminationspan> according to a poll by <span class="word-wrap-span">NPRspan> in October 2017. 

Most of the policies that trigger such an attitude, like race-based <span class="word-wrap-span">affirmativespan> action in university admissions and job hiring, obviously pale in comparison with what has been <span class="word-wrap-span">endurespan>d by Native Americans and by black slaves. One does not need to accept the concept of “reverse <span class="word-wrap-span">racismspan>” to see why tolerance of extreme, generalising statements about whites—or whatever you wish to call them—are so dangerous. Such <span class="word-wrap-span">remarkspan>s are <span class="word-wrap-span">seizespan>d on by those who are <span class="word-wrap-span">nostalgicspan> for a time in which America was supposedly great, but only for a single race.
